**INSTITUTION PALLIATIVE CARE CONSULTATION PATIENT NAME: **NAME[AAA, BBB M] ACCOUNT #: **ID-NUM **ROOM ATTENDING PHYSICIAN: **NAME[YYY XXX ZZZ] CONSULTING PHYSICIAN: **NAME[YYY XXX ZZZ] DATE OF ADMISSION: **DATE[Jun 02 2006] DATE OF CONSULTATION: **DATE[Jul 02 06] HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Briefly, the patient is a **AGE[in 70s]-year-old woman with the past medical history significant for coronary artery disease, CABG times two, AVR, aortic root aneurysm, infrarenal aneurysm, and a thoracoabdominal aneurysm with dissection. Her care was then complicated by thrombocytopenia following heparin while in the OR, believed to be HIT, difficulty weaning from the ventilator and tracheostomy, MRSA, left bilateral lower leg weakness postop which has been more on the left recently than the right, bilateral subdural hematomas and most recently left lung collapse with repetitive bronchoscopies. The patient also has had a 3B cervical cancer for which she just finished radiation therapy. We were asked to see the patient for depression and pain. On talking to her, she says that she does not have any pain. She has some mild shortness of breath. She also notes some fatigue and sadness. She was started on antidepressants roughly two weeks ago at 20 mg of Celexa. It is hard to talk to her because she is intubated, so it is hard to tell whether this has improved or not. The nurse's feel that it has not and that is quite teary all the time. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Past medical history is as noted in the chart. MEDICATIONS: Medications are as noted in the chart.
SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient has a living will, and the primary attending talked to the family, and the decision was that it would be okay to do short-term ventilation and to do simply things like colostomy but not take her back to the operating room. The patient is a Christian. ____________ Symptom Assessment Scale is positive only for the fatigue, shortness of breath, and the feelings of sadness. She just had a bronchoscopy and Versed, so she is still relatively fatigued. FUNCTIONAL STATUS: The patient is blind in her left eye. She is quite hard of hearing. She is dependent on all ADLs through this acute hospitalization.
PAIN: The patient had a Duragesic patch, so it was taken off today when she dropped her hemoglobin. FAMILY HISTORY: Family history is unobtainable. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: GENERAL APPEARANCE: The patient is a somnolent female who awakens and can follow simple commands. She is quite hard of hearing. She is wearing glasses. HEENT: Pupils are equally reactive to light. She has a tracheostomy. Mouth is grossly normal. CHEST: Lungs: Decreased breath sounds on the left. Regular rate and rhythm. She has JVD at the clavicle. She has no S3 or S4. ABDOMEN: The abdomen is soft and nontender. She is slightly distended. She has a G-tube. EXTREMITIES: She has some cyanosis and coldness of her left foot. She does have pulses. NEUROLOGIC: Neurologically, she is grossly nonfocal. I cannot rule out extensive motor examination. LABORATORY, RADIOGRAPHIC, AND OTHER DIAGNOSTIC STUDY FINDINGS: Her laboratory data was reviewed. Her hemoglobin has markedly decreased. ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 1. Pain. I stopped the Duragesic patch because she was hypotensive. Will leave the p.r.n. medicine as the patient is not having any pain at this time and will follow. 2. High risk for decubitus. Does not have any decubitus at this time. Will need to watch carefully. 3. Depression. As the patient is already on Celexa, increase to 40 a day. Will try to evaluate more fully when she is more awake. 4. Goals. The patient has a living will. The primary team is in talking to the Durable Power of Attorney, so we will follow at a distance. ___________________________________ **NAME[VVV M.
